This is a Electric Guitar Plug Plate which is particularly designed for my Yamaha Pacifica, so I don't know if it will fit with other models.

This Plug Plate was helpful for me because the original Plate of my Guitar (Yamaha Pacifica) broke and I needed to replace it and it works perfectly fine.
The object is getting printed upside down, so the surface of the plate gets smooth. But the disadvantage of this is that the beveled edges of
the screw holes might not be printed so nice.
You can always feel free to flip the object 180 degrees.
If you use ABS it's probably best to thicken the object on the Z-Axis because otherwise it wood be too flexible. And you need to watch out to not screw in the screws too much because ABS tends to crack/break.
If you use PLA you can just leave it like it is.

comments.text: Realistically, it isn't that likely, I would guess.  At 5 m of head, you would get exit velocity through a nozzle of about 9.9 m/s if the nozzle is ideal.  Angled at 45 degrees, you're looking at a horizontal range of 11.32 m if the nozzle (and motor, remember) are 1.5 m above the ground.  That leaves precious little room for any inefficiencies or air resistance, etc...

author: pmrfin

title: A Fractal Spiraling Network Which Corresponds to Hyperbolic Space

description.text:
A Fractal Spiraling Network Which Corresponds to Hyperbolic Space
See https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YqhNUCir7iI&li for a description of the system. My website
https://sites.google.com/site/richardsouthwell254/home
has loads of free 3D printing resources (design apps & stls) on it.
The structure forms fractal, highly clustered parts around the perimeter, with bridges over the middle which make travel easy. It can be thought of as the net of a self intersecting surface.
About the thing.. The shape was grown from tiny rules, starting from a cube. The network cannot be drawn on a sphere without edges crossing. It can be thought of as the net of a self-intersecting surface. If one keeps growing the surface, it basically makes hyperbolic space. The number of hops between a randomly chosen pair vertices is surprisingly small.It has this `small world' property just like social networks, protein interaction networks, the internet, etc.
If you do not have a printer, you can buy it here
http://www.shapeways.com/shops/croco
Version 3 looks better, but version 5 is easier to print because it has a flat base.

This is a remix of Johann mini kossel effector and carriages to use 6/32 threaded bolts that come with the Dubro 2268.
http://shop.dubro.com/p/6-32-heavy-duty-ball-links-2-pkg-1 Goals:
  • Use the Dubro 2268 instead of Traxxas 5347 ball links
  • attach lock nuts from the outside using a single 6-32 threaded rod.
  • get maximum range of motion.
  • clear belt movement zone of nuts.
    • I found that for the carriages, the original design (locknuts on outside, extra cone-shaped spacer) was needed to keep the lock-nuts from effecting the range of motion. for the effector, using the bolts that came with the 2268s they did not require any locknuts (so far) if they do I will re-attach them the same way as the carriges. I wanted more of the little code shaped spaces that come with the 2268, but I was unable to find any. So I scored some cone shaped beads from micheals art supply. I also found another part called a "Brad Hole 6-32" from lowes and used them on a second set (posted under makes). I recently found that misumi carries similar parts:
    http://us.misumi-ec.com/vona2/mech/M1800000000/M1803000000/M1803050000/ I am looking hard at WSSS6-4-2

title: A Complex Polygonal Network Making A Warped Sphere

description.text:
This structure grows a highly complex pattern of polygonal faces with different numbers of sides. The growth rules are simple and deterministic and so one intuitively picks up on a kind of cohesion behind the form. It is also very interesting to see how the surface bulges and warps as a result of the different polygons included.

author: mortinus

description.text:
My homepage video describes shows off this shape, amd describes how it was created (starting from one little cube, and following very simple rules!)
Youtube video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wxwvMNF_m2k&index=1&list=PLCTMeyjMKRkrhMSOf0SD677liIG6aaZ_3
Also, my website
https://sites.google.com/site/richardsouthwell254/home
has loads of free 3D printing resources (design apps & stls) on it.
This particular structure is very interesting, because it has lots of hidden details (chambers & such) which ca only be seen be peeking through the holes of the model. If one sliced the shape in half, a surprisingly elaborate interior would be revealed. Some parts of the model have a fractal form, but there is variation in different parts (like in the Mandelbrot set). This mixture of self-similarity and hetrogeneity gives the structure a strangle organic feel.
Again this object can be bought directly

Having to cut the Kaptan tape with scissors from the roll every time i needed a small piece, was driving me mad.
This object holds a roll of tape with a core diameter of about 77mm, and here it is 22mm wide. It could be made as wide as you need with a bit of work. I may post a wider variation later on.

The print is relatively non critical.
I made this one in PLA, 2 perimeters , 0.18 fill.
3mm hardware was used.
The "cutter edge" is from an old aluminium foil roll box. I salvaged a small length and had to cut it in half lengthways to fit the printed groove.
Take care that you do not cut yourself with this serrated edge. SAFETY FIRST.

comments.text: I like your design aesthetic on this one!  The simplicity of the function coupled with the perhaps unnecessary, yet exceptionally charming circle motif is great!  The truncated waffle grid to support the tape roll is clever too.  Nicely done.  I may ponder and adapt some of your methods for my own work.

comments.text:
Thank you for your insightful comments !
The idea for this object popped into my head mostly fully formed, as do many of my designs.
I tried to make it 'look right' , or have a 'balance' , it is difficult to put my thought process into words.
I am glad that you liked the roll holder, it was a case of, good enough is the enemy of the best, i felt i could do better, but lacked the time. The constraint of holding the roll shape as well as alignment were my guides.
While i am not trained in the arts, i do have an eye for pleasing shapes.

A simple piece to mount a dial test indicator in place of the hotend on a RepRapPro Ormerod.  
I got a cheap indicator that didn't have any easy means of bolting it in place, so I made this bit to just have the housing sit snugly in, and that grabs the fixed part of the arm. It is held in place tightly enough by friction that there is no risk of it moving during use.  
You need to take off both the hotend and the nozzle mount and attach this in its place. The indicator arm will be in the same position as the hotend nozzle.  
It is a parametric design, and should be easy to adapt to DTI's of different dimensions.

description.text:
I needed a spool holder for my new printer, the DW-BOT (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:375231) and I came up with this.
I use two different filaments, the ColorFabb filament that comes on a 50x200x55mm spool (Inner, outer, thickness) and some cheap Chinese filament that comes on a 30x150x89mm spool, and I wanted it to fit both. Also, I wanted to to be adaptable to future spools.
The idea is to screw the "Generic Screw" part to a panel in the printer, using the "Back" part as a inside off-load of material stress. Then create different "Nuts" that fits the individual spools and screws onto the screw.
So far I have printed only the 50mm Nut for my ColorFabb filament, because this is what I want to test my DW-BOT with.
I have included the CAD files in different formats, so you can load them in your CAD system.
Let me know, if you need other screw sizes for your spools, and I'll make them for you. Replacing the spool, going from a 50x200x55mm spool to a 30x150x89mm spool. Not easy with one hand, the other filming :) http://youtu.be/AzED6K_Vj-g

Mine is printed as delivered here, with 0.1mm layer height and without support.
I used the "Back" part for a drill-guide. Drill one hole, then put a screw in that, drill the next, put a screw in that to hold the guide in place, and so on.
If you feel like it, you can put a 4mm threaded rod inside the "Generic Screw" to keep it from delaminating. I don't think its necessary, but just in case.

title: Bushing for Spool (Filament) with Skate Bearing

description.text:
This is a crude design made using OpenScad, based on the other Spool Bushings out there. This one will fit onto a 1.75 inch spool, like the one I got from New Image Plastics (their 10 lb spool). The skate bearings fit nicely onto the MakerBot threaded rod (or equivalent) and provide alot less friction so don\'t have to worry too much about possible feed issues. This is related to my other changed thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3760). The hole is not exactly round, so I made it a little oversized so didn't have to trim too much off. Do have to worry about too much unraveling as the spools are generally not balanced well. To fix this problem my spool holder tilts slightly to one side, so I moved the spool so it would slightly rub up against the side, as can be seen in the pictures. Optional: If need to secure the bearing inside the bushing, I would recommend using a hot glue gun (I didn't have to)
Have included the OpenScad file so change to your hearts content.

Print two parts
Slide the two bearings into the center of the printed part (might have to be careful when cleaning out the middle).
Mount spool on a MakerBot threaded rod (or equivalent) and start printing away with filament ease.

description.text:
Now updated to make king and rooks more printer-friendly by eliminating horizontal overhangs.

  • How this thing happened: I couldn't find a support-less knight that I liked, so I modified the knight from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34017 by adding a little more support to the jaw.
    The rest of the pieces are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46808 -- the rook and king from that set have been altered to remove the horizontal overhangs.

    • .STL files provided:
    Singles for all pieces.
    2-up for rooks, bishops and knights.
    8-up for pawns.
    Complete set.

I printed in PLA with .25mm layers, 20% fill, no raft, no support.
The support under the knight's jaw can be sawn, whittled or ground away with a high speed rotary tool (Dremel) for a better appearance.

title: LUCAS extruder - finally a really universal extruder

description.text:
UPDATE August 14th

  • Please check out version 2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:428312
    While this is still working very well (the servo version at least), the improvements of the new version are worth it!

    • UPDATE July 29th

  • I have been having an amazing feedback from you, lots of amazing suggestions to improve the design. Thank you very much!
    Unfortunately I haven't had free time to work on it as I wanted, so the project is on a temporary halt. I have updated a couple of files here, correcting some minor mistakes, and I have also uploaded the complete sketchup file; it might be a little messy, but I'm sure you can find your way around it. If not, just shout!
    UPDATE July 5th:

  • See updated instructions
    Video (with english subtitles: http://youtu.be/-h-zzxGWx2s)
    Importante: if you're using the servo version (or if you don't use bed auto leveling at all) you don't need to print the x-carriage, it'll probably fit the one you already have, just check if the standard 50mm holes match.
    Universal extruder

  • This is my first and so far most important reprap project. I grew tired of replacing extruders and disassembling lots of parts every time the nozzle got clogged or I had to swap material.
    So, finally here it is, an extruder to suit all your needs: can be used with 3.00m or 1.75mm filament and with (almost?) any hotend (to be verified).
    The concept behind this project is actually simple: I designed small pieces ("bits", as I call them) and and adaptor inserted in the main extruder that can be replaced anytime you need. Just open the idler and change the filament width; open the front lock and change the hotend.
    I am also uploading the x-carriage designed to work with the BAL (bed-auto-leveling, see below) version of this extruder.
    I also added to this concept everything I always wanted in an extruder: a quick release for the filament, a belt tensioner (not on the extruder, but on the x-carriage) and a bed auto leveing switch without any servo: when the nozzle touches the bed, the extruder rotates and activates the switch. This is very experimental, I don't expect it to work flawlessly, but it is here to be developed.
    So, this is still a work in progress. I haven't even tested it in a real life situation, but I'm making it public anyway so that you can help develop it. I really thing this project has a great potential and could become a standard for extruders.
    As I write this text I'm printing the second prototype, where I corrected some problems, and I plan to put it to work in a couple of weeks. I'll upload photos as parts get ready and assembled.
    Last but not least, this isn't actually 100% mine. it's a remix of several things I found here, put together in this project; see sources for more information.
    Thanks, hope you enjoy it.

comments.text: Thank you for your comment. Wiring and cable management is always a problem, isn't it? In order to make replacements and maintenance less difficult, I usually divide them into three groups: hotend (heater, thermistor and fan), extruder (motor and fan) and x-carriage (servo and endstop). Other than that it's up to you and to your printer configuration on where to run these cables. The hotend group usually runs to the right through that notch in the vertical part supporting the x-carriage. The extruder group has usually no support at all, just loop it around the motor so that the wires don't cut with the movement. The x-carriage group may be trickier, you can use the rectangular holes I left in the x-carriage table to lock a 4-way cable into place. As soon as I can I'll record a video. I'm about to finish printing and assembling another one, so I might make a video of the process. Thanks again!
comments.author: ws1008

comments.text: While looking at the overall no-servo design, I noticed that the endstop will be triggered when the hotend hits the bed. However, when the hotend hits the bed, it will have to lift the whole extruder mechanism (including resistance of the 2 springs and the weight of the motor) to trigger the endstop, that is a lot of weight! Am I correct?
comments.author: lucascorato

comments.text:
It is an interesting idea, but you have to keep your hotend extremely tight to the extruder at all times. If it can move a little, even 0.1mm to the sides, that will surely damage your print.
Although having to lift the whole extruder's weight might look like a problem, it is necessary as to guarantee that the hotend will go back to its original position.
My objective now is to find the sweet spot between "weight lifting" and hotend locking. Either it's too heavy that it will bend your heatbed or it's too light that the hotend will wobble around while printing. My conclusion for now is that you absolutely have to have an active system that will lock or release the movement... Maybe a small servo could do this job. But then you ask me: so why don't you use the servo with the Z-probe? My answer is because I don't get a good repeatability with it. After two or three prints I have to recalibrate it... And it sucks...
Any help is appreciated!
comments.author: ws1008

comments.text: This is such nice work.  I do have one request: I just had a hell of a time replacing the extruder on an old Prusa I acquired to use a different filament size.  All worked out fine, except for how the one tight fitting nut that helps hold the extruder to the X carriage.  On mine, which is one of the reference models, the vertical nut on the right (as you see it from your first picture) is hard to reach if it 'pops' out.  May I recommend to those who are willing, that you dispense with the use of a nut embedded into the extruder (where it mounts to the carriage) and use a thermoplastic insert.  No nuts to mess with and once in, it stays in.

comments.text:
Why would it not be useful? Any company can still use this product, as long as the designs are available to the public. Given that this is a reprap extruder, I don't think the licensing is an issue.
Also GPL doesn't mean "not allowed to use this commercially, ever" it means "not allowed to use this in proprietary designs, ever."
comments.author: oneil

comments.text:
Oneil, thanks for you comment. I'm new here and still exploring. I have changed the license to Creative Commons - Attribution - Share Alike, ok?
Could you please clarify me why a non-commercial license woudn't be useful?
Regards,
comments.author: oneil

comments.text:
Lucascorato, GNU is good. Thank you.
Creative Commons Attribution is good, the share alike tag in this case is 'community friendly' because the derivative works should also be creative commons.
The 'non-commercial' tag is terrible. It restricts how the design can be used. If the extruder were 'non-commercial' does that mean I couldn't print it out and recover costs in time and materials? What if the person using the extruder wants to make money from the printer they are creating? Yuk.
We are building reality here. Why limit people in how they can use it. Let's create and enable others to create and just sit back in amazement at the things people do create. Keeping the intellectual property open means that people can contribute with confidence. We are all just creating and sharing and helping each other out as we build amazing things.
As we build these things, some of them might take off and become really profitable. What happens if that thing was non-commercially encumbered? It means we would have to stifle the development of knowingly violate the IP terms. Yuk.
comments.author: lucascorato

comments.text: Wow, that was very concise and thorough. Thanks a lot for sharing your point, which is very valid by the way. Regards!

This automated turntable helps lazy people like me to get nice scans with a David Structured-Light Scanner. The turntable in action: http://youtu.be/r2YUnTnl1cY VirtuMake is an Open-Source project. Please donate, if you like my work and want to keep the further development of my Open-Source hardware going on. http://www.virtumake.com
Thank You :)
Firmware udate: Version 0.4 -> wiring diagram did not match with the firmware. Thank you @andyman2000 for your feedback :)
New firmware, Version 0.3, released!

This is an instruction to build an automated Aruino Turntable You need: 1) 1 Arduino Uno board 2) 1 10k Resistor 3) 1 10k Potentiometer 4) 1 Push button 6) 1 Servo Motor 7) The printed parts 8) A David-Laserscanner: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36989 Installation Instructions: I) Remove the 180Â° lock from the servo as shown in: http://feh.osu.edu/Design-Project/References/servo.html II) Put all parts together as shown in the wiring diagram. III) Load the firmware (the -ino file) on the board Operating Instructions: Open your David-Laserscanner and activate the option: Seetings > Advanced Settings > Communication > COM > Enabled. This function allows the Arduino board to send commands via the USB connection to the David-Laserscanner. The turntable has 3 modes: Mode 0) Nothing happens :) Mode 1) If you push the button, the turntable starts to rotate. Now you can adjust the angle of the rotation with the potentionmeter. No scans will be made in this mode. Mode 2) Once you are satisfied with the rotation angle, push the button again. The table will stop to rotate for 5 seconds. Move away and let the table do its work. It will rotate, then send a signal to the David scanner. The scanner will make a picutre of the object and save the file. If the scanner is finished, the table makes the next move aso.

author: danb400

description.text:
I wasn't sure exactly how to name this... This is a sound deflector or horn that directs more sound towards the viewer on the iPad mini. It gently mounts onto the iPad mini using the Lightning jack.
I found that the iPad mini's speakers are too directional and unless there's something to bounce off of, dialogues can sound really faint. This little thing does seem to really make big difference!
Just print the 2 STLs and use a drop of super glue to glue them together. Enjoy!
(Modeled from Apple's iPad mini Retina drawing, I think it should work on 1st gen. iPad mini too)

A drop or 2 of super glue will hold the pieces together. Make sure the fake Lightning plug is horizontal when glueing.
Print slow for the overhangs to print successfully, Minimum 2 perimeters or else lines might droop during printing.

description.text:
A little support bracket for the Bosch PS22-02 so it can drive/drill perfectly horizontally.
Just use the included screw intended for the belt clip to secure.

A mounting solution for attaching GoPro cameras to the Solidoodle printer (gen 2). The plate can be latched to either the top front frame or the side front side frame. Makes taking videos or timelapses of the building process easier. There are two versions available:

  • Screw mount - Allows you to attach the GoPro to the plate using standard M5 GoPro screws. A nut is required.

  • Slide / Snap mount - Allows you to the attach the GoPro to the plate using the standard GoPro snap legs. Same as with the standard mounts.
  • The snap mount is a work in progress. Need to tweak the dimensions a bit.
    • Both versions are supplied in two formats.
    One is a complete, solid assembly that can be printed in one piece. It requires printing with support material but should be a bit sturdier.
    The second version is with the plate and mount(s) in different files for separated printing. This requires attaching them together with acetone. Sample footage using the mount: http://vimeo.com/gingerskull/gopro-solidoodle-mount-test UPDATE: Added the slide mount. As with the first version, there is a standalone mount and a combined mount. NOTE: I made this for the Solidoodle 2 frame. I don't know if the original Solidoodle or the upcoming Solidoodle 3 have the same frame dimensions or not.

Just print and have fun filming your creations.
If you opted for the two-part solution - use acetone to bind the mount to the plate.
Both mounts can use the same plate. Indentations on the plate allow for easy center-positioning.

title: Snowman Gift Tag w/ Initial: Negative Cut
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Quick Printable Gift Tag w/ Initial
Frosty visits this tag for your loved ones!
Complete alphabet available! Happy Holidays :)
My inspiration for this came after I spent well over $10 on "artsy" gift-tags of various designs. They look GREAT on the gifts, but I honestly hate throwing them away. It seems like another huge waste that isn't necessary this time of year. So here you have my customized monogram gift tag. I wanted to make something small, beautiful, that was as memorable as something you'd find in the store but that I could print at home. I have put this design through a few changes, but really just to accomodate multiple symbols.
As per suggested, I am entering this in protoparadigm's December Design Contest! I'm so honored that this tag has been used and can spread the joy of the holidays and love of 3D printing at the same time. I hope that you find this gift-tag as fun to print and tie on a gift as I did. Happy Holidays!

100% Infill
Print one out for every gift! Why buy the tags at the store when you can MAKE THEM :D
Please note the model has been modified to be a complete cut-out versus just the center of the letters. This will save a LOT of time :D

This is normally done at the start of Christmas dinner (the jokes are read and you all wear your hats during the meal).  
Print Cracker.stl, the others are just the individual parts, but have not been oriented to the platform for printing.

title: Replacement rotor for CNC spindle drive CNC 3020/3040

description.text:
I've a 3040 Chinese CNC router. The spindle motor has a plastic part on the top of it. To my understanding it has a role of cooling the motor. the rotor blades in it are completely vertical ones what only helps to gravitational cooling (the warm air moves upwards) and not forcefully cool the motor. My other problem that the motor I have (230W one) has no integrated encoder, so I can't measure the rotational speed.
I designed a replacement of this plastic part with fan blades in it and an encoder ring around it. The encoder ring has exactly 60 holes, what allow to measure the rotational speed with a frequency counter without modification.
Notes:
  • The part's height is smaller than the original one, because I've no double extrusion 3D printer to print support material.
  • I haven't printed it yet so I've no idea if it has any design flow.
    Update 07/03/2014:
    • Created a model of the whole thing
    • Tweeked the rotor based on the model
    • Added the opto holder ring
Only the two STL file printable. The model is just for demonstration.

comments.text: I made one. I did not leave it on, as it produced quite more vibrations than the original part, without a significant increas in Air flow. My Motor only has a small hole for Air outlet..
comments.author: harrygeier

comments.text: I built one of these, modifying it slightly to fit my 500W spindle thats 57mm in diameter, also changed the the number of holes for optical sensor to 30. When I tested it it made me realise that there is quite a science to air flow, despite the logical thinking that the blades would "pull" the air up and away from the spindle assuming clockwise rotation. It turns out they do the oposite I  assume by creating a vacume under the spinner. Even so I can report that the spindle does indeed run cooler. I am going to try modify the blade design, maybe looking a bit more like the "Dremel Devil"
comments.author: TuxSoft

Led mount for desk This is my first attempt at a 3D model. It is a mount for holding some LED strips to my desk. Originally the lights in the hutch would blind me while sitting at the desk, so this was to help make a proper and clean looking mount for the strips. There are channels and a hole to hide the wire and a nice slope to angle the light into the hutch. The LED's used were sourced at http://www.superbrightleds.com/moreinfo/led-light-modules/falm-series-rectangle-flexible-accent-light-module/832/
Just a quick sculpt over the old Bowser game character for someone ;)

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46884 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=46884

I haven't printed it out yet (it's about 18th on my to-do list...) but it looks sound, I'm pretty sure the facial size should fit most heads but at worst, I suggest printing the middle section first to be sure, if that fits ok you know the rest will be fine. I've cut it for a Rep2 size platform , in 3 sections but I included the full mask incase you are lucky enough to have a large printer and can do it in one hit. I have made no attachment system, I figured there is a gazillion ways to attach it, velcro, elastic.. a baseball cap backwards... it's up to you really. I figure if someone is actually going to print and paint a Palpatine costume mask, you are going to be wearing a Robe, so I have made enough of the mask to show when you wear it with a hooded robe. Enjoy, and may the Force be with you, Always...

A fully customizable set of counters for the Italian "Tombola" (Bingo) christmas game.

In the .scad file you can choose either to generate a single counter (a cylinder with a number engraved on both faces) or a whole range from number to number:
You can also customize cylinder diameter and height and text dimensions (see the comments in the file.
The set is generated in rows of 10 elements. A sort of underscore (as in the original counters) is provided to differentiate similar numbers (such as 68 and 89).
"font_DesignerBlock_hi.scad" is used to generate the numbers. This file must be saved in the "libraries" directory of OpenScad.
WARNING: The code uses lots of RAM and CPU. I recommend to keep the range small (max. 30 elements)

Upgrade part for Nerf Praxis to allow slamfire

I had a good hard look into my Praxis and found a possible way to upgrade it to slamfire.
Only the part I call lockplate (because its only function is to block the release if a lock is set) needs to be replaced for that. This is work in progress, I havn't got it to work right now. The mod changes the function of the trigger from pushing the lock plate to release the spring, to blocking a secondary new spring (rubber band, etc.) from forcing the lock plate to release. This, paired with a new pusher extension which returns the lockplate to its non-released state via the pump action mechanism should allow the gunner to just hold the trigger and load and release shots just by pumping. The balance between the trigger and this release spring need to be carefully balanced.... On the parts picture you can see a few iterations of my part, together with the original one. If you get it right, plz share! =D Oh, disclaimer: I did not laser scan the original part, I reengineered it in Sketchup8 (I really need to learn a better tool).
And: If you break your Praxis, hurt yourself, make baby jesus cry... Sorry, not my responsibility.

title: Hover Craft Inspired Spin Top
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I had this idea of making a hover craft that could be propelled by balloons, but that idea didn't work because balloons weren't powerful enough to keep the propellers going. The whole thing ended up spinning on the table rather than hovering in the air, which led me to turn it into a spin top that would keep on going and going if you pump air towards either the propellers themselves, or into the opening duct in the centre of the thing. It'll speed up and keep spinning until you want it to stop!

I've uploaded 3 different files here. Spin top.stl - printing everything in one go. The propellers will have supports underneath, which will need to be removed and then re-attached to make them spin. The 5 caps are to be glued to the spigots to hold the propellers in place. The ball is to be glued to block the hole at the bottom of the object. Spin top (body).stl - the main body only. Spin top (propellers and bits only).stl - the propellers and small parts are separated from the main body so there's not as much supports required as in the whole set.

comments.text:
Okay, I love the concept, and I'm no physics major, but looking at the design, it looks like you have the air pumping into the tips of the props. This seems counterintuitive for two reasons: There's not enough force, and No lift capability. Not to mention the whole thing about faster air current equals less pressure means that the top is being sucked to the surface. ( I see it, but can't explain it better, sorry.)
So, to fix? How about the vents come out near the center of the props into a much smaller turbine type chamber underneath the props, and having the turbine exhaust come out on the bottom. Turbines attached to the props could have a tighter airflow from the vents to help with increasing torque while the downdraft from the exhaust would also help in lift.
Also, I agree with the CO2 cartridge idea. I recommend suspending the cartridge from the bottom and adding legs to the vehicle to keep it off the surface for easier launching.
If I ever get around to actually designing one myself, I'll send it over to you first. ;-)
comments.author: PArtzzles

comments.text: You're problem is the torque imparted from all the propellers spinning in the same direction. The torque from each of them sum up to make one large torquing moment. Multicopters overcome torque by making every other propeller turn in the opposite direction, which would mean youd need an even number of props (4 or 6). I wonder if that would solve your problem.
comments.author: octopus

comments.text: Thanks for that! I shall give it another try when I have time to draft up the CAD model. I'm thinking having 6 props and alternating the air duct directions. See how it goes! :D
comments.author: octopus

comments.text: Oh and like you said, making the propellers in opposite direction too...I wonder what will happen if I use the air pump to make it go like in my video, but instead of spinning it might just lift up?! :P
comments.author: idea_beans

comments.text: It did cross my mind to use some sort of continuous air supply to power this thing, but I think the design is slightly flawed in the way those 5 air ducts were placed, which made it spin clockwise when the air flow comes out.
comments.author: idea_beans

comments.text: what if you used a CO2 or air tank to power the device thru the middle port?

This is a basic calibration model for a 3d printer made to save time and filament. It measures 1" in all three axes with each leg measuring 1/4" square. Volume: .16 cubic inches
ABS Weight: .01 pounds

• Print the part using the provided .STL file. All dimensions are in mm (except above).
  • Use a caliper to check accuracy per the specified dimensions (1:1 size of 1")
  • Adjust printer calibration parameters and repeat as necessary
    • Notes:
    Low extrusion temperatures and/or use of a fan is recommended while printing the Z "leg" Update 12/23/12: Changed the .STL to metric dimensions, the resulting part is still 1" cubed, but the .STL dimensions are now in mm.

comments.text: This is a very bad idea. The error on a printer is an absolute error. Adjusting settings so that this prints to exactly one arbitrary imperial unit will result in a percentage error. When you print something larger you will find it is out by a few millimeters rather than the smaller absolute value.
comments.author: DanielDC88

comments.text: Your statement is well intentioned, but short-sighted by assuming this is limited to position calibration. This model works great for fine tuning extrusion parameters, temperatures, and fan settings for small parts. It also helps evaluate orthogonality.
comments.author: DanielDC88

comments.text: If you have trouble with the small Z riser consider printing two of these are something else at the same time that is at least as tall.
comments.author: wd5gnr

description.text:
This device, sometimes known as a gauss gun, uses 1/2" cube Neodynium magnets and 3/8" ball bearing, to 'launch' a single ball bearing from the end.
I have tested this with up to four blue sections (5 magnets), and it it perfectly safe to catch the bearing by hand.
The device is modular, so you can start with the two red pieces and a single white clip to hold them together with a single magnet. The red pieces have two holes to allow the use of photogates to measure the speed of the ball that starts the chain reaction as well as the speed of the ball that leaves. This allows one to calculate the energy imparted by each magnet. In addition the blue magnet sections have a single hole that would allow timing of each 'triggered' event for additional analysis (if desired).
Just on its own, it is fun to load and shoot. To load place three of the ball bearings at each magnet (on the firing side). You then drop a single ball bearing into the chute and it fires a ball bearing from the end piece. You will then have one of each three ball bearing that have moved to the next magnet. Reload and refire!
Happy Fourth of July!

title: Parametric VX2-compatible Torbachev Inductor Shield Plate

description.text: 3D-printable Torbachev Inductor Shield Plate for an original VX2 unit.

I couldn't think of anything to get my father for the holidays and I remembered our wonderful times working with the old VX2 in our basement growing up. Mom said he still had it in the basement but it stopped working long ago. Over Thanksgiving I took it back and found that it was in decent shape for a 30+ year old unit except the Torbachev Inductor Shield Plate (TISP) had totally fractured and was no longer holding the Bron Oscillator firmly enough to facilitate RÃ¸genheim-band emissions. I couldn't find a single compatible (or incompatible for that matter!) TISP on Ebay and of course there's no longer any company around. I couldn't find any new-old-stock from Russia which is where Dad got the replacement plates when the current one had hit Yalgeth Limit. I thought I'd give a shot to 3D printing one and amazingly, even though it's just PLA it seems to actually work fairly well. The RÃ¸genheim emissions will never approach 6 Ã¥ngstroms again, but it's completely serviceable. I have no doubt that others with VX3-VX6s will want to try this TI in their units, so I made the rotation angle of fins on the Honeycut Junctor fins parametric. Looking forward to seeing Dad's face when we fire the VX back up over the holidays.
  • Adjust Honeycut Junctor angle in SCAD file if required before printing.
    This file should work as is for all but a VX2/j14 model which used a proprietary TISP connector (happy to fix up the file if someone can forward the measurements, I haven't seen or heard of anyone using one since that incident in Albuquerque in '78).
  • Insert the Bron Oscillator in the large cylinder and GENTLY use an M3 screw to tighten it. CAREFUL Don't dent or ding it, that can shoot the Siegel Resonance Coefficient through the roof and that's NOT a good way to go. It might be a good idea to check the resonance on the bench to ensure you're getting at least âˆ†.991, it's a bear to adjust the oscillator after insertion. It's easy to forget to check the resonance when you're focused on improving your RÃ¸genheim emissions, but that's a mistake you only make once!
  • Open the VX2, remove damaged TISP and use four M4 nuts bolts to attach new TI.
  • Fire it up, take RÃ¸genheim readings, adjusting Hilbert Coils to maximize the RÃ¸genheim emissions to at least 3.7 Ã¥ngstroms. I'm getting ~5.6. If you can't get at least 3.7, try reprinting the TISP at a higher infill. (If you not regularly getting above 3.2, time for a different hobby, you poser!). DO NOT operate a VX below 3 Ã¥ngstroms, it's really not safe.
    • Note: if your diagraphic membrane has expanded due to age or condensation and is arcing against the Honeycut cooling fins, it's safe to adjust the Honeycut tilt to about 9 degrees, but I wouldn't go any less than that. Probably better though just to get a new diagraphic membrane or try to remove the moisture from your current one by putting in a bag of rice for 2-3 days. Please be a responsible VX module user and discard your old or damaged shield plates safely. Your local VX club can help here, or ask on http://www.reddit.com/r/VXJunkies/. If your VX has not been turned on for at least five years, it's probably doesn't have special disposal requirements. I take no responsibility if you damage your VX2 with this TISP - but I'd like to hear about your successes or derivations. Related! I know there's a lot of VX module fans here - have a look at the SK BT-1284u VX Illuminator I found in my dad's basement. Seriously, he had an original SK I never knew about. I don't know what occasion he was saving it for. I can't find the manufacturing date, but it's either a '62 or late '61 model, not sure when the introduced UV? It still works - can you see the glow in the photo!). The Pauli Flux clamp with the Nixie readout (pictured on the left) that that they gave him in college still works too! What a piece of gear that is. Feels really solid in the hands, and incredibly accurate.

title: Chevrolet key fob protector - 1999 2008 Tahoe and other models
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a 1999 and 2006 Chevrolet Tahoe.  The key fob/unlocker remote doohickey has the same profile on both.  I wanted something that would make them a bit different, so it would be easy to grab the right one.  
As a added bonus, it keeps one of the previously broken fobs with a cracked case held together held together quite nicely.  
I might make this a bit thinner and less tall next time a round, but it works just fine as is.  
This will likely fit other Chevy/GMC vehicles as well.

Just shove it onto the fob, it is a snap fit.
It's small, so print at 100% fill with two walls and support for the overhangs if needed. *Another maker has stated that using a brim/skirt helped. If you have filament printer, it might be a good idea!

title: 40mm Fan Bracket for Jonas Kuehling's RepRap X-carriage

description.text: This is a bracket to attach a 40mm fan to Jonas' Reinforced Prusa X Carriage with Slim LM8UU Holder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18657 ), which has a stub on either end to attach accessories. I built my printer two weeks ago, and this is the first thing of my own design I printed on it. I probably made a stupid mistake... just let me know. Technically, it's mostly parametric. If you plug in dimensions for a larger fan, it should all scale... but it won't fit between the axis rails. But you could easily adapt it to something else.

openscad files are in the ZIP archive.  (The easiest way to include multiple required files.)
I printed at 30% infill.  It's pretty trivial... bolt the fan to it, bolt it to the carriage, plug the fan into your controller.
12/18/2012: Be sure to aim the fan so it doesn't blow on the nozzle.  I had problems with the nozzle dropping 10C and "prevented cold extrude" errors when the fan kicked on.  I'm working on a better ducted version that will only hit the part.

author: astein3

description.text:
I kept knocking over the test tubes from my API Master Test Kit when testing the water in my fish tanks so I made this to make them a little more stable.  
It holds upto 8 tubes that are MAX 12.75mm OD  
It says "fresh" on one side and "marine" on the other to prevent me from confusing the water samples when testing from both tanks of mine at the same time.  
The fit is nice and snug, safely holding the tubes even when inverted, but not so snug that you think they'll break.

Prints easily vertically (left edge down to build plate).  
I printed mine at 60mm/s 0.8walls and a very slow first layer, around 30mm/s and 20% infill.  
Doesn't need support, although i did have two initial attempts come free of the build plate, so maybe you could try a brim support though in the end it wasn't 100% necessary.

description.text:
This a very useful general propose holder - at least a cover around two nails which looks likely
It is made to put some note paper on the wall, hang up some important papers like tickets for coming concerts or just to use it as a twin hook fore something.
There is the possibility to put a pen on top and the rods have the size and distance of a standard puncher. So it's easy to punch a paper and then you can hang it up.
The Nails are incorporated into the two rods - easy to hammer them into the wall. The knobs can be fixed on the rods by turn them 90 deg.

Standard printing with 2mm
Use 2 pcs. 1.4x30 nails
The knobs can be (as in the pictures) made shiny with some acetone treatment

This version of chess for three players. You can read more on how to play this game, history and much more at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-player_chess
All figures and board done from acryl. Also attached 3 versions of cases: from acryl, cardboard and acryl+3d printed coners. You can choose whatever you prefer more.

I used figures from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6593 and author of that thing used figures from thingiverse.com/thing:855. Cut all figures from file chess_all.svg using laser cutter from 3mm acryl. Adjust scale a little to make parts connected to each other with some small force or glue them together (I suggest glue parts only to pedestal and do not glue vertical parts to each other to not have traces from glue on transparent acryl). I glued figures with dichloroethane (C2H4Cl2). Generally it is not glue for plastic - it is dissolvent of plastic, but it works perfect to glue details from transparent acryl as completely don't have any traces (in contrast to any glues). But you can also use glues that you have (also very good will be polytrifluorochloroethylene - special glue for acryl or you can glue with thermoglue or even usual cyanoacrylate glue).
Board done from two layers: bottom layer just single peice of acryl 5-6mm (to add rigidity to whole construction) and second layer - board squares glued on it. I glued board squares and border around using double-sided transparent glued tape. But sure you can use any glue from mentioned above (dichloroethane, polytrifluorochloroethylene or others that you have). If you do board not from transparent acryl, then you can choose almost any glue for plastic.
Labels on board border also cutted from blue acryl and installed into holes on board border.
Board on images was done as a gift, so there are greetings on back side done on transparent self-adhesive film.
Also there were done 3 versions of case for chess figures: from cardboard 0.5mm, from acryl plastic 2mm and from acryl 3mm + corner details printed on 3D printer.

Just print file Case Paper.dwg (Case Paper alone.cdr) on 0.5 mm cardboard, cut and assemble. You can use a little glue for small petal that you'll push through holes in bottom to fix them on other side of case bottom, but even without glue it should be fixed well if you did holes of right size (accurate).

Cut file Case.dwg (Case.crd) from 2 mm acryl and assemple using a little glue for acryl or plastic. There are 12 sheets to handle figures and 5 sheets that makes sections for figures of each color. Beter start from attaching internal partitions to bottom part, then glue sides and then front and back panels. Top part done very simple - just 4 sides and cover sheet.

Print case panels from file Case (Plastic Sides).dwg or Case (Plastic Sides).cdr using 3 mm acryl. Print details to connect plastic panels:
  • 4 x Rounded Corner (9 mm);
  • 4 x Rounded Corner (9 mm + 12 mm);
  • 8 x Rounded Side (9 mm x 144 mm);
  • 4 x Rounded Trailer (9 mm x 43 mm);
  • 4 x Parts Connector (9 mm x 144 mm) or 1 x Parts Connector (9 mm x 144 mm) x4
    I used glue for plastics Plastic Fix to glue details but you can use any polytrifluorochloroethylene glue or any glue you have.
    Use 4 x Rounded Corner (9 mm) + 4 x Rounded Side (9 mm x 144 mm) + 4 x Rounded Trailer (9 mm x 43 mm) + 4 x Parts Connector (9 mm x 144 mm) to glue bottom part of case and 4 x Rounded Corner (9 mm + 12 mm) + 4 x Rounded Side (9 mm x 144 mm) to glue top part of case. Parts done such way that there is small border on bottom part that fix top part if proper position.
    Rotate all details when print so flat sufrace be on bottom, as some parts only possible to print with good results only in such orientation (corners even specially done not simmetrical to be able print then with fine quality on printer without support material, but they should be oriented bottom with flat surface, so all walls are vertical). All long details should be printed vertically.
    To make gift looks better I also added small bag from blue velvet for figures.

• chess_all.svg (chess_all.eps) - Chess set (acryl 3 mm). Print 3 sets of different colors
  • Board 3 Players.dwg (Board 3 Players (alone).cdr) - Board for 3 players (acryl 3 mm of two-three different colors, outer shape is for bottom layer that is acryl 5-6 mm).
  • Case.dwg (Case.cdr) - default case from acryl with individual handlers for every figure. Just cut and glue it. Slots and plugs makes evident how to assemble case. On right side done case cover (it is 1 mm larger in every direction). All done from acryl 2 mm.
  • Case (Paper).dwg (Case (Paper) (alone).cdr) - easy to assembple case from cardboard 0.5 mm. Black lines should be cutted, blue lines used to blend cardboard to form the case with cover.
  • Case (Plastic Sides).dwg (Case (Plastic Sides).cdr) - flat panels for case done from acryl 3mm + printed plastic connectors
  • Case 3D printed details.zip - all printed plastic details in one file
  • .STL and .SLDPRT files - plastic details to be printed on 3D printer.
    • Enjoy with your friends ;)

title: Portaberry Pi Frankenstein/Zombie remix plus flat face case unit mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 5/31/2015 -- I had some trouble with the amplifier wiring and with user Veladrin's help I changed the wiring. A new diagram (rev.3 is posted). Also -- note in the step-by-step the configuration instructions are for RetroPie 1.9 -- for any newer releases, some of the directories have changed. I plan to post an updated how-to with new instructions, and this will also include a new design for use with the RPi 2. This is a set of modifications to 3Derp's awesome Portaberry Pi design. Big change - the case mod here allows for direct mounting of the joystick and the face buttons without the plates -- looks a little more streamlined and allows for a logo to be placed on the front face.
I also posted a connections schematic and a very thorough step-by-step how to guide to accompany 3Derp's image gallery. This is good for any Portaberry construction
Small changes - I mixed up the speaker plates as well as the Joystick and button plates with a splatter effect. Looks pretty nice I think. Whoops - noticed one of the face buttons was off center by a couple of mm -- fixed and uploaded as topmod 1_1

YOU CAN DO THIS -- it is challenging but well worth it. The connection drawing and the step by step should allow you to get through the assembly. This is a very cool project and I wanted to make it easier for other people to make one.
Thanks again to 3Derp. If I got anything wrong let me know and I'll fix it.

title: Universal spool holder for square beam (parametric)

description.text:
NEW VERSION HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1070481 This spool holder is using 4 standard 608zz roller/skate ball bearings to limit friction.
Print two supports then insert the bearings onto the pegs. They are designed to hold firmly the bearings. In theory your spool holder is ready but if you plan on using it without the rollers make sure the supports are stable and that the flanges of your spool are exactly parallel (they often are not !) otherwise you will risk a drop and to brake anything fragile beneath. Space the support so that the flanges will lie onto the bearings. You can put any spool size on it, you are just limited by the size of the frame.
To be more secure you can print two rollers to fill the gap between the bearings. You are now limited to spool widths less or equal to the length of the rollers but this setup is more stable. I provided a picture with this setup.
Provided STL is for mounting on 25mm Makerbeam (Bukobot).

comments.text: The spool that toppled over was with paper sides, and had slight bump along the circumference. A new design with the spools further apart would surely have helped. Also, to aid stability, the grip on the aluminium bar could be much deeper, using the full size of the bar, and perhaps with a small indentation to grip into the bar track. Another detail: the centre round thing of the holder interfered with the spool so that I could not push the bearings fully home.
comments.author: egil

comments.text: Novel design, absolutely. But a bit too daring - after having had two incidents of a 1kg spool toppling over (luckily with no damage) I no longer use it.
comments.author: egil

comments.text: What was the causes ? Maybe you have a bigger diameter spool ? Are your rollers smooth and are they spinning freely ? Anyway pushing the arms further away from each other to improve stability is certainly the way to go. I printed mine with compacity and had no problem but it could be a big plus for security. I just ensured the sides were firmly attached. Otherwise the sides can detach from the rollers with the vibrations and so follows the spool.
comments.author: egil

description.text:
I received, and built, the MakerGear ceramic heated build platform and am very happy with it, except for the aluminum plate that sits on top.  I have it taped down but it was still sliding a little, not much.  Didn\\'t want to attach it with something that could be hard to take off later in case need to change something, so this design was born.
The design uses the existing M3 bolts for the build platform, couple extra nuts and washers, and hold everything in place nicely.  Have been using the design for building my last 10-15 things and so far has held up well.
A modification I did to the HBP from them was to wire up all the contacts (except for the LED light) directly to the ceramic piece underneath.  I was having connection issues so epoxied the wires underneath the connections.  These brackets should work for the standard install instructions.
Used Catarina Mota's shapes.scad file, which have uploaded.  I could not find the original post for it to give her proper credit, but thanks soo much Catarina!

Print both stl files, the left (unlabeled) and right. Difference between the two is the hole offsets for bolts.
After printing and cleaning, follow these steps to install
1 - Remove HBP from the Makerbot
2 - Remove screws from the mount (keeping track of which went where
3 - Place one bracket on, and secure it in place with the original bolt and an additional washer and nut (to secure the bracket) on each bolt
4 - Repeat for other bracket
5 - Level all the bolts off (to have a level platform) and tighten all the nuts down. Do not go crazy tightening them as it is easy to strip the threaded inserts out of the wood (trust me). Just tighten enough to hold it.
6 - Place platform back on and align everything. I had to use needle nose pliers to put the bolts in place as hard to move platform around with the brackets (exact point).
7 - Heat up and build. One thing which I am tempted to do, but haven\\'t yet, is get longer M3 bolts (believe they\\'re the standard 16mm length) by maybe going to M3 x 20. This is so can put nut and washer underneath to secure it a little more, but that might be overkill, plus I don\\'t have any.

comments.text: OK, I printed these, but I must be daft!  What do they connect to?  Do I drill holes?  I am definitely missing something....
comments.author: neoteric

comments.text: If look at the STL files, there are two holes on the base of the unit, for each piece.  I had to enlarge the holes a little bit using a knife just to make it easier on me and so can adjust it better.  The holes are offset a little so it does make a difference which side it goes on.
comments.author: neoteric

comments.text: I must be daft.  My HBP is held on by six bolts.  Thanks for the reply. :-E

I have some awesome spools of filament from Printrbot and wanted a hub to use with bearings. This thing is that thing.
This is an early work. Of the get go I see it could be a little over built in areas and under built in others.
Update: The *mk2_fixed.stl file was ran through cloud.netfab.com to fix it since slic3r was previewing it weird.

You may want to edit the STL or Alibre file, I have added support in the bearing area of the hub because I couldn't get the slicer support material to stick well. In most cases you may want a pair, so you will need at least:
  • 2x 608 skateboard bearings.
  • Appropriate lengths of threaded rod or hex bolt
  • Spool carrier
    • Update 12/15/2012: The bearing area is a bit snuggle to undersized, scraping and sanding will be in order. I'm working on an update that fixes this. The axle hole doesn't need to be the same size as the intended axle, it actually needs to be larger then the axle hole in the bearing but smaller then the bearing well. This is also being addressed. Update 12/16/2012: Uploaded mk2 files. These should fix the tweaks in the first pair.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Bought this GPS speedo for my Blokart but it doesn't have a useful way of mounting it on the handle bar shaft so I designed this.

This needs to be printed out the way it comes to ensure the layers have the correct orientation to prevent splitting.
Print it out then slide it onto the handle bar shaft from the bottom, it will spread slightly as it passes the bend near the top and this is why it has the split down the side.
Use two M3 machine screws approximately 15mm long and 2 x M3 nuts.
Secure the GPS with a couple of 3mm x100mm cable ties as per the photos.

description.text:
Holly and I are teaching a two week intro to 3D printing, modeling and scanning at Marwen, an art center for under-served youth in Chicago. Our plan is to have the students design their own action figures initially based on a templates / designs we provide. This is the first iteration of Marwen - a bit blocky perhaps - but hopefully awkward enough that the students will want to improve upon it more. I'm not really happy with the hands either - so that will be addressed in ver2. Also in version two we will optimize the parts for FDM/FFF a bit more, use less support material etc.

remixed_from.title: Lötfanten – Soldering aid, third hand, etc...

title: Lötgnu - Soldering aid, third hand, etc...

description.text:
Inspired by a wooden version, created by the "Eigenbaukombinat" Makerspace in Halle, Germany, I just had to make a printable version of this. I changed everything a bit to fit to my personal preferences better, so the general form now reminds me more of a Gnu than an elephant, so I changed the name accordingly. But the credit is due anyways, you will find the original design here (german page):
http://eigenbaukombinat.de/invasion-der-loetfanten/
It now has a nice base plate with an easy accessible, slightly lowered area to put small parts into, without the risk of having it roll out. Feel free to modify.
You will need two standard clothespin springs for the assembly. Four M3 bolts with fitting nuts are helpful, too, but not required.
I added three different bases, just choose which one you prefer the most.

Print two upper clamp parts, two lower clamp parts, connect both with a standard clothespin spring (as can be seen on the attached photo).
Use four M3 bolts to attach the clamps to the base plate, the clamps feature little traps for the M3 nuts at their base. You can use glue if you do not have any M3 bolts lying around.

comments.text:
Thanks for the nice idea and sharing your design!
However, on my prints the nuts were not fitting and I had to adapt the base for fitting to the lower part. You should really consider to add an air gap of around 0.5mm ...
comments.author: socke

comments.text: Air gaps would help in getting them fit without the use of force, I grant you that, but I tend to pull the nuts into their place while tightening them the first time. It will make sure that they are sitting tightly and have enough plastics holding them in place. Too much space will give them the opportunity to break free through shearing off the material that is holding them. I made some bad experiences in this regard. But that is of course a matter of personal taste. :)

remixed_from.title: The Openscad General Library of Relativity

description.text: I designed a hotend you can make from a template. Print out the template, wrap it around a metal rod, and drill anywhere you see a hole. The design uses a bowden cable as an isolator, so only the metal part requires drilling. Detailed instructions can be found here. I've been using the hotend for maybe two weeks now and it still works great. The small width of the bowden cable means there's less thermal conductance, so it makes a good isolator. I don't use a fan, and I still thermal creep is not an issue. I did notice it works better though if the bowden cable is cold when you screw it in - when it heats up, the teflon expands faster than the metal, so inserting it cold will make a firm grip when the nozzle is hot, resulting in fewer leaks.

Download and print "hotend_template.stl". Wrap the print out around a 1/2" metal rod. I prefer aluminum - it's cheap, easy to drill, and it conducts heat well. Drill anywhere you see a hole. You'll want the finished piece to match the diagram, below. The size of your drill bit should roughly fit the size of the hole. Check the table for recommended sizes. Pay close attention when you drill the hole for the bowden cable - you don't want to drill clean through the metal. Just drill far enough that you can easily drill the rest of the way with the tiny bit you use for your nozzle. I mark my drill bits with some tape to indicate how far I should go. The aluminum will start to deform right before you hit the other side, which will serve as a warning for you. Once you're done drilling, take a hacksaw and cut off your piece from the metal rod. There's a groove in the template that's meant for this purpose. Use an M4 (8-32) tap to ream some threads into the holes you drilled on the top side of the piece. This will leave some metal shavings inside your nozzle, and these will cause nozzle clogs if you do not remove them. I screw a bowden cable in and out a few times until I'm sure I've removed all the shavings. A more thorough method might be to plunge some PLA in and out of the nozzle until clean. You can optionally file down the bottom sides to ensure the nozzle tip is the only part that makes contact with the bed, though I've heard some people say this isn't necessary. Insert the heat resistor and thermistor. Secure the heat resistor with an M4 screw, making sure not to damage the resistor. Drill a 3mm (1/8") hole into your plastic hotend mount and use a long M4 screw to attach the hotend to its mount. A second M4 screw can be used for additional support, however I did not use this second screw in the prototype, shown above.

A Rework of :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302633
I changed the design a bit, added support, should print without warping, Mine did!
Print at 25% infill at .2mm layer height for best results.
Also added a stl for bearing extensions for 608ZZ bearings so you can use smaller spools on it.
Branded with my Business Name, MakerFront.
Cheers!

This is set up for 8x30mm bolts and 608zz bearings.
Parts List (as I used):
6x 8mmx30mm bolts
6x 1/2 nuts for 8mm bolts
8x 6mm washers
4x 608ZZ Bearings
The bearing extensions are press fit, make sure the bearings are flat in there to limit wobbling.

title: Misting fan to pressure sprayer adapter.

description.text: I created this item as an adapter between an 18" misting fan I purchased from home depot (expects garden hose) and a chemical sprayer pressure tank. Useful when you want to use the misting feature of the fan but do not have a garden hose water supply nearby. It may also be useful for other projects.

Make the print as solid as possible to make it as water tight as possible. It will be under some pressure from the tank. It may also be a good idea to use teflon tape on screw side.  
The garden hose thread pattern was obtained from the hose to bathroom sink adapter listed in sources.  
I have yet to do this but it could be improved by enclosing the larger opening in the garden hose to a small opening. This should make the walls in that area thicker and less likely to leak.

description.text:
This is a little electronics project box based on a similar box that I bought from Maplin. 
Overall dimensions are 115x78x34
Tap the holes in the box to M3, and attach the lid using M3 screws.

I like the idea of constrained sketches available in FreeCAD. This is a hack to transfer them to OpenSCAD without too much trouble.
This Thing is an adaptation of Dan Newman's excellent Inkscape plugin (parent Thing). The main changes are:
1) Runs without input and saves .scad in the same folder as .svg file (see instructions below)
2) Does not extrude shapes, but keeps them two-dimensional
3) Ignores some transformations, and units, to get same size in OpenSCAD units as in the FreeCAD sketch.
4) Minor technical changes to circumvent ugly crash bugs in Inkscape (and FreeCAD's svg export, I think)

Usage (outlined in attached images):
  • Make sketch in FreeCAD,
  • Export sketch as "Flattened SVG" under File -> Export,

  • (Windows) Run Inkscape plugin from context menu.

  • (Other OS/Or don't want to install context menu) Run the following commandline
    • inkscape --verb=EditSelectAll --verb=SelectionCombine --verb=EditDeselect --verb=command.extrude.openscad_auto.noprefs --verb=EditUndo --verb=EditUndo --verb=FileQuit /full/path/to/file.svg This commandline opens your file in Inkscape, combines all paths and then runs the export plugin. The full path to file is important, it is used to determine the output directory for the SCAD file. Prerequisites: Freecad, Inkscape Installation:
  • Install Inkscape plugin (see parent thing by Dan Newman for details).
  • (optional, but convenient) Make context menu, shell script or whatever you prefer to run inkscape from the commandline as per above.
    • To install a context menu in Windows 7 (like the one in attached image) I made .reg-file which installs the menu for svg-files, and runs Inkscape assuming it's installed at the default location. I attach this .reg file, but a) never trust a .reg-file from random internet people: check the contents yourself, and b) edit the file to match the location of your Inkscape.exe . If you are not comfortable with .reg-files, there is a guide at
    http://www.howtogeek.com/107965/how-to-add-any-application-shortcut-to-windows-explorers-context-menu/ , make a command for "svgfile" which runs "c:[backslash]Program Files (x86)[backslash]Inkscape[backslash]inkscape.exe" --verb=EditSelectAll --verb=SelectionCombine --verb=EditDeselect --verb=command.extrude.openscad_auto.noprefs --verb=EditUndo --verb=EditUndo --verb=FileQuit "%1" (sorry for [backslash] -- thingiverse removes them automatically it seems) This is very much a Work in Progress, and it has not been tested at all. It just happens to work on my machine, with my settings. It should probably do something to .svg's generated with other programs as well, feel free to try.

Printed initials which can be used in the place of place cards, or just as a nice little thing to have on your shelf/desk. Add an LED tea-light for that little something extra.
I made these for a Christmas meal and gave one to each of our guests. Everyone really liked them so I decided to share! I've put the STL of my initials here so you can see roughly what's going on, all other combinations are in the 'Placeholder_all.zip' archive.
If your looking to make in batches of >20, with the suggested print settings and LED tealights, they can be made for less than Â£1 GBP ($1.60 USD approx) per piece with the LED tealights.

'Placeholder_all.zip' contains all 670 possible combinations of letters. Download, extract and print with the lettering down (the STL's should be in the correct orientation). I can fit 6 on my prusa Mendel with no trouble and I normally print with a single perimeter, 2 top/bottom layers and a 15% infill. For 3mm filament this uses about a meter per place-holder. To add that little something extra, get some LED tealights (I found some on ebay) and tack them onto the base with a little glue (I used hotmelt glue, though many other household glues would work). For those who're interested, I have all the sourcecode and instructions on github here: https://github.com/benhowes/Placeholders Thanks to:
papakin for the openSCAD font converter - https://github.com/pipakin/OpenSCAD-Font-Importer
Braydon G. Fuller for the open source font 'Linear Regular' - http://openfontlibrary.org/en/font/linear-regular

title: SAMSUNG NOTE 10.1 2014 Edition - Car Vent Holes Support

description.text:
Quite difficult to use a Table car without opportune support.
I did this one that allow a simple bracket for the Land Rover Discovery 3 using the Vent Holes as fixing points and the plane below as support.
Please notice that the fixing position of the tablet with this support is inclined of round 30 degrees from vertical (parallel to the vent holes in that car above.

The fixation on Vent Holes is using a sliding part one per side) kept in position with a small spring (size of the ball point pens).
The Fixing Plate need to be printed as per file and mirrored to obtain the two side: the two Fixing Plate are then kept together with two rod (I did used two M5 thread rods, length approximately 133 mm, to be fine tuned in place). I also put M5 nuts to fix them better.
Assemble all together, put the spring between the sliding hooks and the fixing pin (help them to slide using a small quantity of spray grease on the rails) and fix in place having the attention to left round 0.5 mm gap per side to allow an easy insertion of the tablet.
1st July: improved the sliding hook that is too small and difficult to stay in place with a bigger one.
Now it is composed by two pieces (A & B) glued together (and again they need to be printed as they are plus another couple mirrored for the other symmetrical side).
I slightly change also the Fixing Plate (the 'New' version) that have the back hook fillet reduced to increase the overall run of the sliding hooks).

title: Printed Stunner into Self starter business!

description.text:
I used to own a Taser for self defense. Everyone would ask me where I got one, and how much they are. They were $999! Waaaay too expensive for what it does.
So being the 3D printer and inventor that I am, I designed my own and made improvements!
I call it the ZunGun! I made the website ZunGuns.com
I gave it a laser site & LED flashlight built in, 16 different colors, and 3 prototypes later it protects you from up to 20 feet! 200% more range than that Taser I used to own, and only 30% of the price!
Any ideas for design improvements?
I wish to show off, and get feedback.
This is not an offer to sell anything.
  • This thing is NOT open source. It is not a shared design. It is my property but I will give credit to those that wish to contribute and want their name in the design credits!

comments.author: ooxtcoo

comments.text:
Thanks for the tip! I should look at rechargeable batteries then.
However the Handel has almost no room due to all the electronics, trigger, and voltage regulators for the laser and lights.
Unless I find small, thin batteries and work them into various places around the body of the unit.
It only really needs just one 9v batt, the second is just for extra backup/redundancy.
I went with the 9v thinking they are common, low cost, and readily available.
Some 9v batts have a 10 year shelf life, and to be honest this is a thing that someone will hardly ever need to use in their life other than for emergency. Do rechargeables have a good shelf life?
comments.author: ooxtcoo

comments.text: Yep, for limited use, primary batteries are best, as you said they hold there charge better / longer than rechargeables, Enloops or LSD AA batterys will hold charge, the given the circuit your using, stick with 9v, as it only has a low current rating....if you don't have current limiting, and are relying on the battery limiting the current, as the 9v would do, then using a battery that could push more current could be a very bad idea, as you only need 8mA across the heart to stop it....however I can assume you have current limiting right?? as if you did not and someone modded the unit, with a different power source, even at 9V, with no current limiting, you would be pulling more current than 2.8ma for sure from any battery other than a 9v battery....hope this helps...K
